content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												This game is freaking great. Don't let the EA ( early access) disclaimer fool you the game is in late beta and will be fully finished this year. Grim Dawn is useing a modified Titan Quest engine and it shows the improvments. Grim Dawn is the only ARPG game that i don't mind spending hours trying to farm loot. The multiplayer is pretty good, although you may experiance moments of intense lag in large fights. Grim Dawns art style hits its them very well. with the music complementing the atomosphe.  When i play at night with my headphones I can get creeped out with the ambiance.  Combat  In Grim Dawn is great and you feel your characters power as you grow. This game is challenging and you will need to carefull early on, Grim Dawn does do a decent job of keeping comabt challangeing up untill the end. Grim Dawn does a good job at keeping up with it post apocalyptic theme, from merchents who overcharge their wares and having the currncy be peices of iron, to the scavenging of food to restore your constituion and the run down towns and farms. if any of this intrest you or you are a fan of this genre it is totally worth the price.  ps please excuse my typosAFTER RELEASE UPDATEGrim Dawn is still a great game and most of what I said still holds up but their are some problems that have surfaced.Combat: The comabt is still challanging but because of the nature of ARPG it is easy to become extreamly powerful now on the surface this seams to a problem, but it isn't and here's why usally they trade  survivalability for damage, most mobs on normal and veteran settings are not going to poseany threat, but once they get into higher settings it will balance out.Now there is the opposite to this spectrum with trading dps for surivalbility (I like the idea of being unkillable), again this isn't a problem but I will point it out since I am here. Like the "glass cannons" the "Battle turtle" will have to change in the later game mods just to beable to kill bosses. In normal it takes forever to kill things but you will never have to worry about dying.voice acting & cinematic: It is okay for the most part, I wasn't one of the plebs asking for it, but it is sufficient for being tact on. The opening cinematic is something to be desired it isn't really good and is to full of cheese for my tast and I love the army of darkness.Multiplayer: Oh boy this is a big problem with me the game constently suffers from lag spikes and with players getting freaquent diconnects (I never join servers I host them so I think it is only happening to people that joins servers) it is frustrating, but not unplayable unless you are doing SoT or CB or playing HC(also can we stop using the word hardcore to define permadeath it's stupid masochist mod is more accurate).immersion: Grim Dawns theme is a post apocalypse with a HP lovecraft twist and it delivers. They way some of the npcs you find are just disheartening from a crazed loon living in a infested city to a father considering doing something horrific. There are many good people in Grim Dawn brought to apsolute despair and are jsut trying to survive. The way Grim Dawn handles its world building is very hands off. You find many nots in the world through breakign verious bookshelves and finding stands with tomes on them. These where the games lore, you can read them at your leisure in your journal. The wrting in these notes are top notich and the few that I have took the time to read are like reading pages from a novel. one of my favorites are the origins of sillth definitly chilling. I am left wanting to learn more about this games mythos, from the old gods you fight against to the other deities, you even get to meet one in game.Over all this game still holds up and is a steal at 26$ BUY IT NOW, DO IT, DO IT NOW!!!!!!!

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								One of VERY few early access games that has consistently impressed and pleased me.On Gamplay: It's an ARPG, so you can expect gameplay in the same vein as Diablo, Path of Exile, or Titan Quest. If you're coming from Titan Quest, you'll likely feel right at home; the game incorporates the Mastery system from that game, and interface is a (much improved) derivation of that interface. One thing to note is that, where characters felt a little... stiff in TQ, characters feel considerably less so in Grim Dawn.Also, wonderful gore and particle effects serve only to enhance to hilarious Titan Quest ragdolls that you know and love.I can't recommend it enough.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								edit - le sigh, farewell to Wyn, my lvl 27 Battlemage. Loving the Hardcore mode :)This game is great, hands down. It works in the 'Diablo style' without feeling like a clone or a knock off. Let's face it, there are really two names right now when it comes to the Diablo-esque ARPGs - Path of Exile and Diablo 3 (all right, so Diablo 2 is still going, I know, but we're talking modern). I like this one because it manages to not feel like either of those titles. -The pacing is decent - I keep moving forward and it never really feels like I'm slowing down. -The loot system feels tight, I get upgrades at a fairly regular pace but you never seem to know when that awesome piece will be around the corner. The item upgrades that you find are also interesting and useful right off the bat. I never feel like I should hoard them because I'm always finding something new. I'm sure down the road there will be big bad endgame style pieces but for now it's managing to stay fun.-The class system. That's where this game really shines. I've been making new characters and playing them to level ten to experiment with the mix-n-match the game provides and so far it's been a positive experience. Things I wouldn't mind seeing in the future - a little more information regarding how certain classes synergize with eachother, what skills play well with others, etc. It's early on right now so I'm not as worried about it (and let's face it, theorycrafting is half the reason fansites exist) and I'm having fun with the experimentation.-No persistent online connection. I cannot stress how awesome this is. Will it lead to some cheating? Probably. Do I care about that when I just want to play by myself or with a few buddies? Not in the slightest. Considering that the place I live has terrible internet having a proper Single Player Mode is absolutely crucial, my ping time can get over 1000ms and I don't need to explain how quickly that will get you killed in D3 or PoE. With this game I don't have to worry about it, just fire it up and away I go.So far so good guys. It's amazing to see what's been done (especially considering the age of the engine running underneath the hood) so far and I'm really looking forward to what the future holds. Well worth the price tag.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
												This is a Neutral review, but due to Steam's 'Love It Or Hate It' voting system, I'm selecting against it due to how the end game works.The game itself has four acts, with each act consisting of a major plot arc as the main character (you) explores the land to unite with survivors and repel an otherworldly invasion. I mostly enjoyed exploring every nook and cranny during the first act. Then that feeling died quick as the game placed valuable upgrades throughout the area, making the exploring portion mandatory to stand a chance at later difficulties. I spent 40 hours with my latest Hardcore character (not dead as of this review), and clocked 27 hours of those 40 exploring the map for shiny shrines and attributes gained through side quests. It was a struggle to beat the game the first time by act 3 and took several breaks to get the urge to finish the rest of the game. Overall, the 'Normal' difficulty version of the game is worth checking out.My main gripe with the game is it relies on difficulty being resistance based. In the game, there are 8 major resistances and 3 other important damage types not covered by the major 8. If a player is able to get a resistance stat above 50%, the game allows for a struggle in the fight, where that player can take a hit while delivering damage and not instantly run at the sight of taking damage. Coupled that by having only 1 healing potion to use at a time, a person playing Hardcore has to grind previous difficulties to get their resistances up or they will die, no exceptions. It made it very boring because I couldn't progress the story for the later difficulties at all, at least safely.The game further chooses to disrespect the player's time by not providing a reliable means to improve the most common 4 types of damage: Vitality, Aetherial, Chton, and Poison. Elemental Resistance is plenty in the game, so much so, it almost shouldn't exist where I got a shoulder plate to drop that gave +30% to all elements on top of the 40% element resist from Shrines. For those four I mentioned, there are almost no significant ways to improve them through Components (items you socket into items) and Augments (items you earn through factions that apply on top of the components), meaning you need to get lucky and hope an item drops with what you need.Damage bonuses are flat multipliers, so damage quickly becomes fixed if one doesn't use multipliers through curses or items that decrease resistances or defenses. The game doesn't support glass cannons properly because of that and teaches over time to just focus on defense because your damage will be good enough for almost all the fights. Only when my resistances weren't high against the damage type I was facing was I concerned about needing to do damage in a quick manner.I could probably write about 3 pages worth of complaints in design decisions with information to prove those points, but to save your time I recommend playing the game through Normal difficulty and stopping there, even though the game gimps most characters through their Shrine system having the rest of the Devotion points be available in later difficulties. It'll be a massive time sink gearing up a character to handle the later difficulties with no progression in completing those higher challenges.

												An amazing game all around.Pros:- diablo 2 atmosphere (pretty "grim", as its name states) and bloody- lootfest (gotta get all those epics / legendary items)- good difficulty balancing (you'll always feel like your character could die if you don't pay attention)- amazing Devotion and dual-class system, super varied, allowing many different playstyles- respec-ing is basically free, the game encourages you to try many different ways to play the same character- killing enemies feels rewarding (nice effects etc., and loot, lots of loot!)- 4 difficulties (2 for the first playthrough, then 2 others for additional playthrough like in Diablo 2)- you literally need 2 min to start the game and get to the monster smashing action, no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t (esp. nice when you want to play for a short time)Cons:- sometimes it's a bit "too" dark (you may want to adjust your screen lighting)

content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
Product received for free
												If you loved DIablo and Diablo 2, this game is the♥♥♥♥♥♥  Pros- Extremely expansive and detailed character build system.  110.5 hrs in and I could keep making characters for years!  The synergies between the skill trees, constellations, augmentations, components, etc. is very deep.- Great graphics and scenery.  The world is beautiful, monsters and gear look great.- Great crafting system- Grimdark setting that is actually grim and dark.  Like the journals I found of a family that resorted to prostituting their 11 year old out to survive, eventually turning to murdering the johns and canabalizing them as they succumbed to the blood god.  Savage.Cons- Too much loot.  Set your filter to yellow as a minimum, green is better.  The amount of trash loot is simply obscene.  That and "rare" items just rain form the sky to the point that you will find yourself swapping out Epic/Legendary items with a copy that is .001% better on a somewhat regular basis.- Difficulty is disappointing.  Too easy most of the time, then occassionally you get an enemy that is over the top.  Wish it was consistently more difficult without the giant spikes.  Won't be an issue for many, but if you are good with numbers, this game will feel like easy mode a lot of the time.- The map system is lacking.  The world is expansive and fantastic, but finding your way around can be annoying until you get familiar with the world of Cairn.- The default camera I feel is to claustrophobic and does not do the game justice at all.  Get Grim Cam and spend some time getting it set up to your liking.  It is a VAST improvement that really makes the world come to life.It has some flaws, but still worth it and the only recent Diablo-like worth playing right now imo.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												Summer-Rain awakens to the sight of you danglingfrom a hangman's noose. Gasping, the residentleader-of-the-resistance shoots the rope twice andfrees you. The newly-updated intro cutscene shiftsaway to the main game, and the familiar, isometric2D camera welcomes you into the hellish world ofCairn, where Fallout meets a frontiersman-like Christian dark age.GRIM DAWN."What's going on now, Starboy?" Summer-Rain asks,unsure of the foreboding atmosphere of overturned, burning carts, ruined towns and mutilated corpses and livestock. The living dead stalk the streets and countryside, and strange, otherworldly crystals havesprouted along the landscape, corrupting everything."I have to make my way to Homestead, help the folkholed up in prison with resupplying their food source."Summer-Rain smiles, before asking if Achilles can helpyou with your quest at the Homestead. "Ha-ha, Summer, very funny...!" You manage a wrysmile, before you cross a Reanimator's path, a giant,hulking undead monstrosity with aetherium crystalssprouting from its back, summoning lesser undead tofight you. "What's the story behind those crystals?"Summer-Rain asks, putting a tub of vanilla ice creamin between her crossed legs as she watches you fightthe reanimator. Clicking furiously in this Diablo-likegame that makes Diablo III look apalling, you wonderhow a team of less than ten people did so well a jobcompared to a game where dozens of people workedon and took years to complete in the case of Diablo.You glance at her before doing a double-take, withSummer-Rain oblivious to the suggestive pose she isin, with vanilla ice cream, no less. You explain whilefighting throughout the countryside that the greencrystals; Aetherium, were artificially made and is thereason why the Grim Dawn event happened. Before the world of Cairn changed, it was similar to being a mix of the American Colonies and semi-industrial England. But after the Grim Dawn, with magic commonplace, two otherworldly powers came and fought among themselves over the world- the Aetherials, who possessed physical vessels and saw Humans as both fuel and food, and the Chthonians, enemies of the Aetherials who required pain and blood sacrifices to bind themselves to mortals to grant them aid or power.Summer-Rain tilts her head with the spoon in hermouth, a weird look on her face before she removesthe spoon for another scoop of vanilla. "Doesn't seem like a good deal for any of us humans. TheAetherials wanna eat us and the Chthonians want touse us, even though they hate the Aetherials." Bythis time, you have fought your way to Homesteadand helped their Quartermaster with an insectinfestation, and now the human remnants of anEmpire want to enlist an external faction to combatthe otherworldly menace. You walk towards the Homestead's central area amidBlack Legion guards, garrisoned in Homestead forprotection of both the farmers and for the Legion'sown, the last bastion of sanity in a world gone mad,miles from the Prison-Fortress you called your newhome since beginning the game."Who are these two?!" Summer-Rain exclaims, twocharacters now flanking you, one in dark robes andcloth mask, arcane runes upon his garb, while theother is clothed in white with gold armor, orangeand red accents decorating his patterns of fire andthe sun. "I have to choose now, the faction whichwill assist me in my quest to free Cairn from thesemonsters."Summer-Rain is excited now. "Burn them! Burn theundead influence from Cairn!" She yells, but youalready wanted to play with the Order of Death'sVigil, the necromancers who have a noble outlookon undeath, but are reviled by the rival factionKymon's Chosen, a group dedicated to a Sun Godwhom the Necromancers view as a false messiah."HOW COULD YOU?!?!" Summer-Rain exclaims,incredulous after picking your faction to progressthe story. "They're religious fanatics, Summer!"You try to argue your case, but Summer-Rain isnot hearing any of it. "You're using necromancy!The very powers you're trying to destroy! You'rea hypocrite, Starboy Coldheart!" She sticks her tongue out at you while moving towards the door."Where are you going?!" You ask, not knowingwhat to do now, what with receiving orders togo to the super-secret hideout of the Order ofDeath's Vigil and Summer-Rain about to walk outof your room. She looks down at you in a strange,half-pout."I'm going to get my laptop and play Grim Dawnon my own. I'm going to join Kymon's Chosen andburn the corruption of the undead, the Aetherials,the Chthonians- and you- from Cairn." Your jawdrops as Summer-Rain opens your door andflashes you her signature smile."I Love you... Starboy Coldheart!"A week later, the warrior priestess of Kymon's Chosen, Summer-Rain; faces off against an occultist of the Order of Death's Vigil in the most strangely unbalanced multiplayer host game in an isometric ARPG.All because she wanted to burn undead for theglory of a false Sun God rather than use them to combat other undead alongside her boyfriend.GRIM DAWN.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Though still in development this game proves to be challenging and the rotating camera angles are a nice touch while playing so nothing gets missed especially new discoverable routes.The Above review is something I quickly compiled shortly after Grim Dawn launched on Steam Early Access. My glowing review still stands, this ARPG is solid and is by far one of the best games I have enjoyed in a long time. As you take a look at other reviews little to no players say many negative things about the game. Those who do point out performance type issues have points, but Crate has been serious about creating fixes to permanently squash glitches and errors. Grim Dawn is now at the point where more and mroe DLC is being released. 2 Content patches (both free so far) have been released with one adequately priced arena based DLC (on the steam store). Another 2017 early DLC is announced for a new class with an 8th to arrive after that. Crate openly supports modding of GZrim Dawn and the community has been tediously at work making some quality extentions. Do I support this game in the finished state after it's highly successful EA launch? I sure do! It would be a steal and my recommendation to get it on sale but even buying it at full price is worth it in my opinion. At full price you are supporting a highly active and interactive developer studio, encouraging them to continue their fantastic support, and giving them incentive to keep DLCs coming in the future. Buy and play the game, you wont be disappointed!

Early Access Review
								After some hours and finishing act 1, I have to admit that this game has the chance to be the real Daiblo II sequel (in terms of gameplay). Though, the developers have to take their chance and there is still a lot of work to do.Pros:- Skilltree, finally a game that allows tinkering with skills and spells.- Two "classes" in one, or second spec.- Typical Diablo like Hack'n'Slay- You are responsible for stats assignment- Has this "I want to see more and gather items" feeling or at least unleashes it- Futurue support or partly supported already: CraftingCons:- The Titan Quest engine, yes, someone may say it is doing a great job but there are many things this engine is not capable of (e.g., missing shadows, performance issues, etc.)- The gameplay is not that smooth yet.- Only 2 acts until now (CONSIDER: Early Access!)- Crafting is currently not really balanced- Level capThe game has a lot of potential but the devs need to unleash its potential. There are still some things that are not yet finished and will need a lot of polishing.Finally, I recommend this game to everyone who is searching for a old fashioned Hack'n'Slay.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Grim Dawn is great fun! There is so much to explore, tons of sweet loot and interesting quests. While it is based on the old TQ engine a lot of work has been done to bring it up to date and the visuals are great with each area having a distinct look and feel, this combined with the excellent audio makes for a very immersive environment.While I love this game I’m not a big fan of the constitution bar. When constitution runs out and I can’t find anything to restore it, I’m back to spamming health potions. I did prefer the earlier versions of the game where health just restored outside of battle and health potions had a longer recharge. I believe this forced a more strategic level of combat and gameplay.GD has a great community with a committed and experienced dev team. The devs post frequent game updates on the forums (http://www.grimdawn.com/forums/) and are always ready to receive constructive feedback.Can’t wait to see how the rest of this game develops. :)

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												Greetings.For start i would like to say that i am big fan of Diablo 2 and sadly no ARPG that came out after Diablo 2 couldnt manage to bring the same feeling and fun Diablo series had ( Diablo 3 is garbage).And now we have it Grim Dawn!  The developers of the game made Titan quest which was a masterpiece ( didnt play it yeah shame on me :)  ) starting from team of 2 people and eventually grew to team of 10 people and managed to create this GEM.Since the ARPG market isnt that big we have 2 games that are currently the best on ARPG genre which are Diablo 3 ( ugghh) and its Free version which is Path of Exile.On the other hand none of those games reached the pinnacle of gameplay which diablo 2 had. DIablo 3 is just overpriced MMO these days and Path of Exile is a big market for trading gems-skills to make a cookie-cutter builds.Now lets see what exactly makes Grim Dawn a great game and why you should invest your time into it:Dual class system: you get a choice out of 6 classes( masteries) as you start on level 2 and another choice of class at level 10. Although its not forced and you can play 1 class just as any ARPG.Gear gives skills: there are lots of gear and components which can give you different skills as well be it passive or active.Devotion System: There are shrines located in the world of cairn as you adventure , some of them require  to be fixed(different componets required)  or kill a wave of monsters.After you restore a shrine you get devotion point which can be spent according to your like.Total of 50 shrines can be obtainable.Factions: you kill monsters for a faction to get respected with them which unlocks gear and augments to boost your character even further.    I  can go on and on about game features but the game is awesome and worth every penny you give for it.3 Difficulties; Normal, Elite, Ultimate. 4 Huge acts to complete. 2 roguelike dungeons for more challenge. The game is content complete and fully playable which awaits some polishing and launch at February. Lets congratulate the developers on making such a badass game with little budget.  Cheers

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
Early Access Review
The ShortPros: Awesome combatIntense settingReplay abilityDepth, so much depthCons:Depth, so much depthOccasional damage spikes (possibly because of locational armour ratings)Difficult to create effective class combinations without planningThe Long:The first thing with an ARPG is whether or not the Action is fun. When you can knock back an enemy, watch it fly and proc an 8 way fireball that hits them as they're flying back, then use a charge skill to hit them again there is a sense of perverse satisfaction. Damn fun.The main issue with Grim Dawn is that there are a lot of skills, and even more items. Which is both brilliant and horrible. It's brilliant when you can find the skill and item interaction that allows you to achieve that crazy combo, and the depth that this game has is astounding, but that's where things get difficult. Unless you've been playing traditional ARPG's since they came out, or can do complicated mathematics on the fly, there is an overload of information finding these combinations may take a while. Grim Dawn partially addresses this with separated character sheets and detailed information, while summarising it for newer players but with so many interactions it can be difficult for new players to understand what is useful and what is not.I always feel the need to plan out the character with a skill calculator, trying to figure out the optimal way to get the most damage out of it. If you're into that kind of thing awesome, if not, beware.Conclusion:If you like the genre, you'll more than likely enjoy the game. If this is your first time playing an ARPG you may need some, or alot of help.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												Titan Quest 2: Steampunk edition. No, this isn't a criticism, I loved TQ, and Grim Dawn lovingly thieves TQ's corpse of a lot of key gameplay elements (no surprise, as most of Crate Entertainment is made up of TQ's devs, if memory serves correctly) Equipment: Grim Dawn's gear consists of a typical loot-fests' prefixed and affixed "Ascended Warrior's [item] of Everlasting Pain and Death of the Fox"-type loot generation, with a fair smattering of weapon archetypes to choose from at the moment (swords, daggers, two-handers, rifles, pistols, crossbows, etc.) You can buy these super-overpriced from friendly merchants in town, or just kill special bosses or minibosses and get drops from them. Armor is spread about, consisting of a familiar spread -- helmet, torso, legs, feet, shoulders, gloves, and then slots for amulets, two rings, medals (like, military rewards, yeah), and relics. These last few are more specialized and, like most other H&Ss, are usually more utilitarian, offering not specific DPS or defense boosts, but general stat buffs. Upgrades: Gear can be 'gemmed' (Diablo 2 callback) in a sense. As you kill enemies, you'll collect fragments of upgrade items. Combine them (just smash them together in-inventory, no need for special NPCs or items) and you get the "completed" item. You can upgrade gear with this stuff at any point, complete or not, with completion usually maxing out the stat/effect bonus the item uses, in addition to adding an additional ability. Certain things will only fit into certain gear (upgrades increasing weapon damage can only fit into, well, weapons). And no, there's no slot-tracking to keep in mind, for better or for worse -- a completed upgrade piece is a big investment into a piece of gear you know you'll keep for a while (or maybe it's just an upgrade that you don't even really like).  Crafting: This'll feel quite familiar to Diablo 3 players. You get a Blacksmith NPC after some time out in the field who will craft stuff for you. This can be randomly-rolled items, or it can be super-upgrades, combining several of the previously-mentioned upgrades into a single, more powerful item with different effects altogether. Most crafting costs one or several of a few unique crafting-only materials you find afield (Scrap, Aether Crystals, and Tainted Brain Matter, to name a few gooey examples). Crafting is also the only way to make Relics, which is an item for one of your fairly-numerous inventory slots. Skilltrees/Masteries: This is what I am very grateful that the TQ devs put into Grim Dawn. What set TQ, and by inheritance, Grim Dawn, apart was the way it handled skills. See, you don't say "I'm a Wizard!" when you start the game, and only ever learn magic spells. What happens is, the first time you level up, you choose your skilltree. Right now, there's:-- Soldiers (lots of general self-buffs and damaging abilities, not flashy but strong)-- Occultists (Summoner-type character, can have a variety of pets or a single strong one, depending how you build it, and with debuffs to cast on enemies and a handful of offensive spells)-- Demolitionists (the ranged class, intended to use guns as there's skills that specifically focus on their use. Has a bunch of 'gadgets' that can supplement DPS, like grenades, traps, etc.)-- Nightblade (the rogue class, lots of movement/positioning skills, with focus on critical hits and powerful damage buffs)-- Arcanist (the caster, has a range of offensive and defensive spells from single-target to AoEs).-- Shaman (sort of like a spellsword, if that spellsword used a two-handed weapon. Skills are much along the path of the Diablo 2 Necromancer's totems.)The coolest part is that, at level 10, you choose a SECOND Mastery, if you so choose. Or, you can refrain from doing so, and simply keep pouring points into your first Mastery. This is a good idea sometimes, as GD also has a very strong focus on synergizing skills -- rather than just give you a billion abilities, you only get a handful per Mastery. But as you level up the Mastery, you unlock new skills that branch off of each ability's "tree", adding additional effects. You can pour points into this new effect for better stats on that effect... OR you can put points into the initial skill.Say you have a magic missile ability, for example. You put a single point into it to unlock it. If you put more points into it, it increases damage of type A. But, if you put points into a skill down the tree, you might unlock an explosion effect that deals damage over time of type B! So you could feasibly just unlock a skill for use, then never touch the initial skill again, if later branches in the tree have effects you prefer. Instant warp-to-town: Hardly bears mentioning, as it is more or less standard for H&Ss nowadays, but yeah. Free travel back to town at any time without needing to carry around town portal scrolls. NOT from TQ, but instead new to GD: you can unlock new areas by collecting enough Scrap (one of those crafting mats, you may recall) and iron bits (the "gold" of this world) and building a bridge. In some cases, this can speed up forward progression... or you can go in a completely different direction from where the game seems to be railroading you. A very nifty way to make you feel a bit less like you're just moving in a straight line through the game.One thing I do find kind of lackluster is building your character outside of skill choices. Character stat-building is more or less dependent on Mastery Selection, as points into the Mastery (which counts as a skill point use, so keep track) will not only unlock new skills, but give you general stat increases relevant to the Mastery (big "Physique" stat increase for Soldier, "Cunning" for Demolitionist, "Spirit" for Arcanist, etc., and a smaller amount of a mixture of the other stats). These are the three stats you can really directly affect, actually. Each is a catch-all for a variety of engine numbers (Physique is Health, Defense value, etc.; Cunning affects chance-to-hit and chance-to-be-hit; Spirit affects your Mana/Energy, damage of spells, etc.) Beyond Mastery skill points, you get precisely ONE (1) choice of stat to increase, from those three, per level. It's a moderate increase, to be sure (like 5 or 6 points), and yes, it's meant to supplement the Mastery's auto-assignment (which is 9 times out of 10 an accurate representation of the stats you usually need for that Mastery to shine), but for some it might feel like it's railroading players a bit too strongly.If you liked TQ, this game is a no-brainer -- It's TQ2, or might as well be. If you're a general H&S RPG fan (liked Torchlight 1 and/or 2, Diablo 1, 2, or 3, Path of Exile, Dungeon Siege 1 or 2, Sacred 1 or 2, etc. etc.), you might want to look through the gameplay videos and see if you might be interested. Otherwise... well, you kind of HAVE to be used to the genre to really 'get' the appeal of this game. If clicking on loot pinatas until they die and mashing Alt to see what they dropped isn't appealing to you, you're probably better off skipping over this one.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								Speaking from only playing singleplayer thus far  - Grim Dawn shows amazing promise. I'm not particularly "into" buying Early Access games, but I showed this one an exception after closely watching it's progress on Kickstarter. I've sunk a good 3 days of playtime into Grim Dawn and it was worth it.I've played Diablo 2 more than any other game. I've been waiting for it's successor and this may very well be it. Even Diablo 3 doesn't hold a candle to this game. Grim Dawn is the remains of Titan Quest's engine - repurchased it's own creators and greatly tweaked and improved upon. Whatever grainy feeling I got from it has it's own charm.Grim Dawn is a game where you're rewarded for exploring and completion. Finding and killing elite or 'named' mobs give bonus XP. Leveling up dramatically improves your combat finesse with new abilities, passive and active. The skill/class system, which was the best part of Titan Quest is still fully imbedded in Grim Dawn. Doing side quests often gives stat or skill points. I like to call myself a 'Completionist." Clearing the map, talking to everyone, doing every side quest. It's nice being rewarded for it and you will be rewarded in this game. You also get to choose where you go and in what order you do a lot of quests. There are currectly 2 wings (acts?) from the main city and you COULD go to the Act 2 area quite a bit earlier then you need to. Crate has added options so you can make decisions instead of making a completely linear game.The loot grind is there. Set items. Uniques. Decent rares. You'll be searching and you'll be loving it. Some gear improves specific abilities and other gear can be used by multiple classes, depending on your spec. A shared stash makes the loot grind less painful when that unique sword drops for your caster. :bI've spent the majority of my time playing non-hardcore characters, however I normally do play hardcore in these types of games. The one character I did play in hardcore I felt like the game was well balanced for it. I think I ended up dying but it was due to my poor decision, opposed to a flaw or unfair part of the game. I do suggest if you play hardcore that you play through whatever content is currently out before jumping into it. Mistakes will be made.Note: This is not an EASY game. You can run directly into enemies or a boss 5-10 levels higher than you and get obliterated. That feeling you have when you die is something that no other games like this give - Freedom. And it's great.Grim Dawn? More like GRINDAWN.... in a good way.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												I will gladly accept any and all quests from an NPC named Captain Bourbon. Especially pouring myself a glass of bourbon while getting a quest from Bourbon so I can reward myself with more bourbon. I'm on a mission...from and for Bourbon.If you enjoy Titan Quest, D2 and Torchlight you will enjoy this one. Very playable for still being in Early Access, the devs have put a lot into this and are active with the updates (see build notes in news). The mobs provide a solid challenge, the skill trees have a lot of customization and the ability to dual-class gives you unique choices for character builds.Update 2.26.2016 - Full Release - 82 hours loggedNo SpoilersSo, I rolled a fresh character after the announcement that it was content complete, as of this review I finished my first playthrough of the entire story (normal diff). I can't say enough positive things about this game, so here's a short list of my impressions:1) The overall story has an excellent pace, it doesn't feel rushed and there's plenty of side content. 2) The Devotion system is a fantastic mechanism that adds a lot of flavor to your build and play style.3) There's a great balance of challenge acheived with combat. At level 50 I felt like I could walk over certain packs of mobs only to find some creature around the corner that would gladly treat me like a pinata. I'll also add that I've started a new game with the same character on Elite, and so far in Act 1 it has continued to present a satisfying challenge. 4) Skills to pay the...Blacksmith? A couple things I'd like to note. The refinement of the skills, and dual class system, has only gotten better since Early Access. Compared to other games in the genre I am really pleased with the fact that the success of your progression feels more deeply routed in skill choice and not primarily driven by gear choice. Your gear is important, but it feels more like an augment to your class and not how your class gets defined. In the same hand, this impacts crafting and in a great way. There's a lot of incentive to craft different items as you learn new patterns, but it's not going to make or break your build. I appreciate that because there's a certain level satisfaction that keeps coming back every time you get a new piece of gear that's an upgrade, and it may not even be that big of an upgrade. 5) Grim Dawn reminds me of what originally drew me into this genre, and refines it to make it fresh and enjoyable. I'll clocking a lot more hours with different classes and I'm definitely looking forward to future content.Lastly: With voice overs, I'm even more convinced, if the opportunity presented itself, I would follow Captain Bourbon into the depths of the void to rescue his brother Scotch (future content idea?)Thank you to everyone at Crate for a great game!

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								Grim Dawn is a spectacular addition to the isometric ARPG family. Created by some of the team that brought you the timeless classic Titan Quest, strap up and delve into Cairn - a world in a 'victorian-esque' era that is experiencing the eradication of the human race.At this time, this game is still a work in progress but it shows a ton of promise. Grim Dawn lives up to its name and paints a canvas of a harsh world where good help is hard to find, suvival isn't always guarenteed and death lurks around every corner. Accompanied by a fantastic soundtrack, I found this game sucked me into its world and I sunk tons of hours hacking and slashing my way to the finish of the current beta (Build 24).If I had to compare it to other games of the genre, I'd say it has the grit and gore of Diablo 2/Path of Exile, mixed with the leveling system of Titan Quest and the fast combat of Torchlight 2. Grim Dawn introduces a variety of its own elements, such as the 'Constitution' health regeneration system, designed to reduce the number of trips to town and potions used so you spend more time in combat. The game also features a choice/consequence system where saving 'character A' means the death of 'character B' and a loss of trust from the faction character B is associated with. There is a ton of loot to reward you for your victories and a variety of options for crafting so customization is certainly an option for your gear.Outside of expected and respected bug fixes, I would like to see: more voice acting for NPCs, more animations for skills and enemies, and hopefully another class (currently there are 5).I highly recommend this game and I look forward to the completed product. Keep up the great work Crate Entertainment!

								Fantastic game. The gameplay is great and alll but, it's the little things that make this game special in my opinion. Early Access Review
								What can I say? Everything you loved about Titan Quest Immortal Throne and more.  The TQ engine has been upgraded with some new tricks, and the new environments and maps are a delightful treat. The best part is the Steps of Torment dungeon which has you crafting a key to open a dungeon that has no access to portaling out, and the key is destroyed upon entry. If you die you have to start over after crafting the key. It adds dynamic challenges to the game. The is an early access game you can trust. The developers have a lot of pride in their project and it shows both in game and in the community. 10/10 would roll another character again and again.

								pro's+epic adventure compared to path of exile imo grim dawn is alot more rewarding for time invested. +fun in depth crafting system.+ real feeling of progression as you lvl up with rewarding drops for the tough battles, No more countless hrs of grinding in the hopes of getting one half way decent item for your build. +faction system is neat with perks. +Secret areas to find hidden loot. +good presentation with very few graphical glitches like some skill animations not disappearing on the AI after they attack not a big deal game is still in development and this happens rarely. +some mobs scale to your lvl for the most part which is a smart way to go with AI. + Skill tree's that are stright forward and easy to understand not to mention easy to fix/undo unwanted skills  to refocus your build without costing you an arm and a leg. +recently saw they snagged a new game design assest who used to work on diablo 2 so i imagine this game will get bigger over time. the map is huge with plenty of room to add at least another 50+hrs of content on top of the already big chunk they already have, i finished my first run through in about 40hrs so much to explore and do i took my time with it i havent even touched the steps of torment yet im gearing up for that as i imagine it will be tough.Con's - This is a random issue that can occur after long periods of playing but the game will stop responding and lock up might be a memory leak or build up of game assests not bing flushed from memory this is just a guess im sure their aware of this but it hasnt been a big enough issue to be to bothersome were talking like 4+hrs of grim dawn app running, only happened once during a boss fight. i havent seen any game breaking issues aside from the random lockups after long play sessions i also cant comment on the networking aspect of multiplayer with grim dawn as of yet so i couldnt tell you weather it suffers from dsync issues like path of exile does - no tooltip dmg numbers yet to account for all your gear passives buffing up certain skills. this is nit picking as its obvious when using a new item if its better or not. - as i was a player coming from path of exile i thought hardcore deaths would send you back to standard as their is no warning label on the difficulty setting when you start a new game i died at lvl 20 and was like oh no want my *&^% toon back lmao. now you know. re-rolled in standard and still died alot in some parts which was fun/ learning exp.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								First time writing a review, it's not really my thing, but I felt I owed it to this game.If you're like me, you read the Bad Reviews to see why you SHOULDN'T buy the game.  There honestly aren't that many bad reviews, which should be a good sign in the first place, but I will save you some time by summarizing what I found out looking through bad reviews, and debunking them, leaving you with no reason NOT to buy this game.First, people complain it's buggy or crashing -- Keep in mind It's early access.  That being said, it's the most stable early access game I've ever played.  I'd have to guess that the people complaining about crashes don't understand early access, or maybe played much earlier on.  I have had 1 or 2 issues in my 25 hours of playtime.Second, people complain it's  not as good as Titan Quest, the story isn't up to snuff, etc... -- This isn't in -any- way a sequel or expansion to Titan Quest. Don't expect it to be something it isn't. Yes it has some of the same staff members who worked on Titan Quest working on this game, but that knowledge is used to understand that they know what they're doing with this type of game.  And if you read the news and updates, you'll see they're always expanding their team, getting veteran game designers/developers/artists to help with the lore, story, and artwork.  Again, it's still early access, and they're working on it.Third, people say "[insert dungeon crawling ARPG here] is better -- Bah, Fan boys!  I love this style of game, and played Diablo 2 so much my middle school AND high school grades suffered.  Diablo, Titan Quest, Torchlight, Path of Exile, the van helsing games... I've played them all and couldn't tell you why anyone would say any of them are better than this game (D2 excluded, cause, ya know... you can't beat that...).  And yes I've played D3 since it came out, since the expansion, and through seasons 1 and 3.  This game is more Diablo than Diablo 3. I'll admit, I bought it half off during the summer sale, but I loved it so much I bought a 2nd copy for a friend and he can't put it down either.  If I have any qualms about this game it's that it's only 4 player max, and the character customization (not to be confused with Class customization) is lacking. And by lacking, I mean non-existent beyond Male or Female.  But that's all bells and whistles, and it's not what makes this type of game fun.  Where the game earns respect is in the innovation and unique ideas they have come up with that make the game fun and interesting, while not impacting the traditional principles that make this type of game addicting and enjoyable.TL;DRHaters gonna hate.  This game's fun as hell!

								Well, I was looking for a new game to play. I like ARPGs and this one looked nice and had good reviews.I knew it would get me some hours of fun so I bought it on discount.I created a character, there was no character customization, I was annoyed a bit.then, I started the campaign.This game... Has SO MUCH POTENTIAL and it is already amazing.The action in this game is more than just running around spamming skills at hordes of enemies or dull bosses like in Torchlight II, here the enemies are varies and have special abilities, you have to know your enemies, and you have to kite them (or build yourself a tanky character which is also possible, but still will require kiting and moving around in combat).The bosses are really well done, the maps are very nice and not repetitive (there's always new stuff to find, eney camps to raid and underground cave-systems and cellars to explore).This game also features an ability to create a portal wherever you are (in dungeon, before boss fights, just when exploring and inventory got full...) and use it to teleport to one of the portals scattered across the entire map.I am a lazy person and this has been satisfying me since the beginning. Inventory gets full in the middle of a dungeon? or after a boss fight? No worries! Teleport to town, sell stuff, bank stuff, teleport back to your custom portal.There are two things that bother me about this game:1. When your weapon has elemental damage on it (like fire or lightning) it is not visible on the weapon itself, only on attacks. I like wielding weapons with effects like they're burning or have lightning around them, just something I personnaly like and think is missing.2. Some enemies feel unbalanced, for example: the "Fury" enemy is a tanky zombie with powerful attacks that has a chance of draining life on hit and shows up rather early in the game. With the help of HP potions they are not a big deal but at a certain point in the game they show up more often and in bunches which I find pretty hard to deal with. So that's challenging but I think maybe a bit too much.Generally, I think this game is definitely worth the full price and maybe even more than that.I like comparing it to Torchlight II because the mechanics and gameplay are alot alike, so I'd like to say that this game is slightly better than Torchlight II as it is now, and it hasn't been released yet, so it has a huge potential.If you like ARPGs and just fun adventure RPGs in general, I highly recommend this game :D

								This is the first  I have been bothered to review for steam.  For an early access game, it is incredibly polished.I have had a couple of moments when the frame rate has slowed, but no crashes and no obvious game breaking moments.I am liking this game at least as much as Diablo 3, which is amazing given the fact it is an inde game. number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								The only other hack and slash ARPG that I consider in the same league as this game is Path of Exile. Just like PoE, this game makes Diablo III look like a game made for simple-minded children. This game has everything Diablo III lacked: Better story,  with a grim setting and atmosphere  that successfully convey a sense of danger and despair. Unchained character development with many options for how to develop your character. Nuance in NPC interactions where making the wrong decision can result in you killing someone who you could have saved. As this game nears completion, I consider it a perfect arpg with no real flaws. Every aspect of the game is well-developed and it is truly fun to play. The depth of character development is impressive, as you can improve your character's stats, pick two classes to specialize in, enhance your abilities by restoring corrupted shrines and investing devotion points in a Constellation system, craft/find a wide array of weapon enhancements and even find relics that give you special abilities like dual-wielding ranged weapons. If you like arpgs with dark stories that don't treat you like an imbecile, this is as good as it gets.

												I invested in this game because I remembered Titan Quest and it's expansion.  I could always see there was something there but unfortunately as game studios come and go....so went the talented programmers that developed these wonderful creations.  I perused Kickstarter and found that Grim Dawn was being created and noticed that not only the same potential was there but something more or just as special.  I invested quickly and not once have I thought it to be hasty.  This game is beautiful and the many hours and months of work have paid off.  Their tone is set well as it has been stated but within it all, there is hope.  I would think that more people will look towards investing in this game because this is really  what an action RPG should be. Crate's small team has done very well with its limited resources and I hope that they will be doing more work.  So please invest in this game.  It's been a wild ride for the limited time I have spent and I look forward for many more hours of playing.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												I play allot of Action RPG games this one outclasses them all. I grew up playing PS2 hack and slash game's like Champion's of norath, when I saw the screen shots for this game I just knew I would love it. What I didn't know was that I would play this game as much as I have. I play by myself, however there is a healthy online community of players who always have servers up for you to join. The gear in this game is creative and beautiful. There are many item set's that link together and give you additional stats or ability's. Most bosses have healthy drop rates. (This was a problem I ran into with titan quest) When you play on harder difficulty's the game drops gear more frequently, When you get to higher levels like 50+ the game will start dropping legendary gear & Empowered lower level gear to match your current level. Empowered gear is gear you get at say level 15 or 30, with triple its original stats so you can use it at level 58 or 65. The game also features a meal system that gives you a translucent health bar that refill's your current health bar when combat end's its rather useful and it is a nice feature on the harder difficulties. As far as the class system goes its just like titans quest, you choose the Soldier tree and say the Nightblade tree and your class becomes a Blademaster. You can mix all the classes like this and make many different characters. There is so much more to talk about, I would recommend this game to any Action RPG gamer. Thank you crate for this amazing game, whenever I felt like something needed to be changed or added into the game it's like you read my mind and changed or added that feature. Crate you have made a masterpiece with this game and I cannot wait to see what y'all do next.

content:
Posted: February 29, 2016
Great ARPG, supurb visuals, excelent design and a great take on the ARPG that absolutely spanks Diablo III right and proper.  I recommend this to any ARPG fan around.  6 out of 5 stars!I backed this game right from the beginning and watched it grow and flourish from a short 700Mb demo to a near 5Gb masterpeice.  Rarely do I purchase Early Access, unless I can see a great future for a game. This game is the true personification of Early Access done right.   I just wish I had more time to play this true gem in the rough.  Full-time studies and part-time employment have cramped my gaming lifestyle severely. (But no one said studying to be a Clinical Psychologist was going to be easy!)I can't wait to see what Crate has in store for us in the future.Visuals: Stunning visuals of a world shattered by the Apocalypse of Monsters and the Undead.Story: Immersive Storyline. (About time for an Original Storyline in my honest opinion).Character Customization: Go for hack and slash or use a rifle for run and gun.  The choice is yours.Playability: I could play and replay this game forever.Overall: This game is Immersive, challenging and all-in-all, a unique take on the classic ARPG.But why listen to me droning on?  Try the game out yourself, you won't be disappointed!

								As a kickstarter backer and person who liked (but didnt love) Titan Quest, I was not expecting something completely revolutionary, and I am happy to say this game... Wow FAR outpaced my expectations.Honestly I got the same feeling as I did when I played Diablo 2 for the first time... this game really  gets it's hooks into you... from what ive seen thus far MUCH better than Diablo 3, Torchlight and other ARPGs and I am stunned just how balanced, playable and fun everything is. (really I'm very particular on game mechanics, and I have to say, everything here is positive, balanced, engaging (I can't even nitpick on little stuff) there's always something in front of you worth doing (quests, upgrades, etc.) I've played more of this game than most big name AAA games this year, (and it's early access, and I havent even scratched the surface of the content here) I've only played a single character (Fighter/Demo) and I am eager to continue with the quest, do some respecing, then start with other characters.Do yourself a favor and buy it today, full price or on sale (for you penny pinchers) it's all good, this game deserves a spot in your library and (to be honest) at this stage as a GOTY contender for 2015.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								Great game unfortunately the multiplayer lacks a closed realm. In other words they lack servers that diablo 2 had in order to host events like ladders etc... A great thing I loved about arpgs was collecting rare loot and trading it for other currency (for instance runes diablo etc.) (path of exile orbs)  or other gear during competitive ladders. I think at one point they discussed the potenial to have their own servers but the cost would be too high as of now. They would need to see how well the game goes over when it's actually released before they can jump the gun on that. Basically finding rare loot isn't as rewarding since people can alter their save files and get whatever gear they desire. If you don't care about online that's great or closed servers that's also fine. I really enjoyed most of the classes but occultist was extremely bland for me. This game has good things about it and bad things. The bad consists of horrible particles, animations and spell effects for abilities. You don't feel powerful with some of the abilities just due to how it looks visually. Some of the builds disappoint me there isn't much of a variety and some skills feel out of place. I was also full of extreme sads when I learned there was no dedicated healer with utility like in Titan quest. I expect the game to get better with time especially when it's released and when expansions come around. It's worth the price where it stands now as they are adding other acts soon. 8/10 for me.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2016
												Damn good arpg.Less streamlined than diablo 3, but also considerably less byzantine than path of exile.Areas are not randomly generated. Like Titan Quest, it is statically made, or seemingly so. Quite a bit of build variety, but like with Titan Quest, I have a bit of a hard time deciding what should get the points. Many options. Less than in  Titan Quest though.  I do not quite like the "invest points" into every single element, honestly I would probably like it more if it was like the POE passive tree where each node only requires a single point (but eh, whatever,  I just do not quite like that way of building up the skills). Damn fun. I should get the crucible dlc, and if they ever make an expansion I will probably get it since the game is very good.Basically, Titan Quest, refined, and instead of bronze age, using a grimdark 19th century setting (not steampunk though, if  you want that, go and try the Van Helsing titles, which are definitely using a steampunk aesthetic, and like this, handmade maps. This plays better).I should try it with a pad. Somehow I do not think it will play as smoothly with a dual analog pad as Diablo 3 does on the ps4 (which is likely the  BEST way to play it, and also overall my current favorite arpg), but it should be good to try it that way.

content:

Early Access Review
								Sunk a few more hours in the game and here's what I've found:Pros: Satisfying combat (ragdolls!)  Graphics feel fresh and unique Map layout and design is fantastic Fairly engaging story Great music Great dual-class system with a lot of options and freedom (so many class options!) Itemization and loot system feels fair Only pre-releaseCons FIXED: 90% of the time when you change graphical settings the whole game crashes FIXED: The game does not have gamebreaking graphics but I have to put most settings to the lowest to keep a good FPS Combat and pathing is sometimes glitchy Ranged units AI makes them try to attack you through walls? Slow development time due to Crate being a small game company (but it will finally be released soon!)TLDR this is a great game if you're a fan of D2 and/or PoE (loyal fans of both!) After the most recent updates, I'm starting to enjoy this much more than PoE.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Лучшая из hack-and-slash игр за всё время существования жанра. Никакие Диабло, Торчлайты и ВанХельсинги рядом не стоят. Сделано в традициях Titan Quest, так что многое узнаваемо по части интерфейса и прокачки, но сильно отличается от оригинала по концепции, атмосфере и контенту.Хоть игра и находится в раннем достуе на момент написания отзыва (завершен только 3 акт), уже есть чем заняться при достижении максимального уровня — охотой на монстров и заработком репутации. Отзывчивые разработчики, большое разнообразие предметов, навыков и всяих реликвий, много лора для изучения сюжета и мира... Это просто идеальная игра. Вот только бегать с кем-то в кооперативе оказалось менее весело, чем в одиночку, но я не уверен, что это минус.Можно играть без подключения к долбаному интернету, что сильно мешает в случае с Диабло 3....Обновлено. Теперь вышла релизная версия и контента стало в разы больше. Да, это несомненно великолепный продукт с кучей возможностей, с огромной реиграбельностью и превосходным будущим. Каждый аспект Grim Dawn на голову превосходит подобные в других играх, в ней собрано всё самое лучшее. Теперь нужно приложить просто титанические усилия, чтобы найти хоть какие-то недостатки. Наверное, это лучшее вложение средств в ранний доступ, которое я когда-либо делал.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								-----The Game Diablo III Could Have Been-----Did you play through Titan Quest, but wish the game had more H.P. Lovecraft and less Rick Riordan?Have you ever wanted your own pet bear made out of thorns so you could grind those bullies at school into a chunky red paste?Were you thoroughly unimpressed by Diablo III but played it anyway because, let's face it, what other options did you have?Have you ever played a fantasy action RPG where guns would definitely have made it better?If you can answer "yes" to any of the above questions, Grim Dawn is a game you need to play (also, if you answered "Yes" to the thorn bear question, you should seek therapy imediately. Such fantasies are not healthy and the help of a professional is strongly advised).For the Low, Low price of $24.99, all of the things below can be yours today (Okay, maybe not today, but definitely in a week if you work hard)!GUNS: pistols, rifles, revolvers, revolving rifles, muskets, cowboy rifles... you get itSWORDS: BIG swords, little swords, stabby swords, choppy swords, tiny swords, blunt swords... ON and ON.ARMOR: Cloth! Leather! Metal! What else?CLASSES: Six to choose from; pick two.TALENTS: a massive talent tree unlocks perks and skills depending on which gods you show devotion to.SKILLS: Too many to list. More than you can fit on your hotbar.The game can be very demanding in big fights. Though most of the time the game sits at a comfortable 60fps (VSync), sometimes I slow down to a 21fps crawl at 1080p max settings on my:core2 Extreme 6850 @ 3.5GHzKingston HyperX FURY 8GB 1866 MHzGTX 970 4GBOh well. I thoroughly enjoyed beating it this weekend! it also has NG+ and NG++ modes for Uber Completionists.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
												I've played about an hour at this point. But that's the beauty of Grim Dawn - it's just a Diablo 2 clone. It's easy to pick up and play for a bit.There's nothing more to say. NOTHING. It's got some neat customization stuff - you like, build your own class? It's weird. But very very awesome. Similar to PoE, but not even close to the same thing. It's great.The music is fantastic for those who are fans of Diablo 1 and 2's moody, grim soundtracks. No other hack-n-slash has ever come close to that. So this is just fantastic. In general, enemy design seems much closer to Diablo, also. Zombies, weird leaping critters, slithering serpent dudes - they all fit in. Character design, I don't know. Not perfect, but good enough. But unlike the Torchlight series, design isn't all over the place. It's not a very cartoony looking game. And this is a big plus in my opinion.Game's about $5 over what I'd pay for this, if I'm honest. The game feels really quite polished, which is surprising for 2016, sadly. I don't really think the screenshots do the game many favours. In general, I like the graphics (blood textures need some work). If things are low-poly, they're doing a good job of disguising this with relatively high quality textures across the board. This is a game that was made for PC, and feels like it.Game's worth a buy, if you're looking for yet another hack-n-slash. This one does it well, which is surprising considering how many I've turned down. Loki, Torchlight, Diablo III I've still played for a whole bunch of hours, got several heroes geared, and most max level, and I am still not really sure if it was really all that good...Grim dawn feels good. It's fun to kill stuff. Good, crunchy sound effects make beating enemies to a pulp extremely satisfying. Which is fantastic.I don't really know how to end this review, but basically, game's great. Get it some time.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Excellent ARPG with a lot of polish and so many possible builds and variations to try it's almost mind-boggling. The fact the devs were fearless and allow the player to create totally unworkable, useless builds provides half the joy of learning and discovery. It's very possible your first couple of chars will be completely underpowered, so you go back and make use of the generous re-spec options to shuffle some skill points around and try again. By the time you've gotten a couple chars under your belt you'll begin to learn what works, what synergizes where, and you're off to the races.The mobs are mostly typical hack and slash fare, nicely animated, and the loot drops in massive piles like it should. Which brings me to the only minor complaint I'd level right now. NEED MOAR STORAGE! You can eventually buy what looks like four large bank tabs shareable among your various chars, but there are SO MANY crafting materials and tempting drops that they fill up very rapidlyOverall, great game, more than worth full price. A LOT of work went into it and it shows. Please show your support to how early access games should all turn out.

Early Access Review
								The gameplay scratches my old Diablo 2 itch. It is fun and addicting. It brings back the same feelings that Diablo 2 did.  It is definitely worth more than what you'll pay for it, even in its current state. It is a solid game despite some bugs here and there, but hey...its early access. Thats a good excuse as long as they continue with the updates. I never played Titan Quest so I don't know how this compares. If I had to compare it to a game that is similiar, it would be Diablo 2 obviously.Gameplay: Fun and addictingAtmosphere: Grim, little boring in colors, but it still looks awesome compared to other ARPGs like PoE.Story: Not really engaging. Doesn't come off as an epic journeyLoot: So far so good!FYI, you get to pick your skills and stat attributes yay for choices with consequence!As fun as it is, I worry that it will suffer long term due to not having dedicated multiplayer servers. Sure there may still be a small modding community that will keep the game alive, but I don't expect it to get anywhere near as big as D2 once was. It is more or less like Torchlight in that sense.Anyways a very cool game even for just the singleplayer experience and occasionally multiplayer with a buddy. Perhaps they'll release the network code for those who want to create server emulations like the old private D2 servers of the past.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												Grim Dawn has plenty of content for those that decide to stick with it all the way through and decide to go even further with additional difficulties or try other classes and class combinations. One thorough playthrough on Veteran (Enhanced Normal) took me around 39 hours with a mix of single player and co-op. The hours per dollars spent ratio is fairly high; however, the experience isn’t problem free. The game performs well on everything maxed and only dropped frames when too many effects were going off. So turn down some of those settings if you’re using a weaker rig and planning to have some co-op fun.Story/Atmosphere Unsurprisingly, the world in Grim Dawn is grim. Humanity is struggling to survive amidst the warring factions all vying for control of the world. The quests aren’t revolutionary, but what kept me interested was the world building aspect. Journal entries waiting to be discovered are scattered all across the land. Some of them are very well written and have tones that range from sad to gross to horrifying. Other entries will give you some history or act as a bit of flavor. The game uses darker shades of color and litters the world with rotting dead bodies, ancient dungeons, mines, and many enemies to slaughter. The game is separated into four acts that all have a distinct visual style and map layouts. Some layouts were better than others and didn’t make you walk around too many blocked paths. I felt much more invested in the world than Diablo 3’s (I disliked most of D3’s story) and grew to dislike one of the factions in GD because of how gross they were with human lives. Let’s not forget that this game is an ARPG and the story isn’t the main focus. So let’s move on to the gameplay.Gameplay This game has a slow beginning pace in regard to acquiring skills. This pacing can become even slower if you decide to take on two classes because for the first 50 levels, you’ll be making hard decisions on what skills you want to give your 3 skill points. You can stick to one class and be a purist which lets you specialize and access the later skills much faster, but I prefer mixing things up. To access later skills you have to put points into a mastery bar to unlock them. This means dual classing can put you at a disadvantage if you don’t have a good plan in mind because specializing with your damage abilities far outweighs having a bunch of weak ones. Many abilities can have passives that enhance it even more, which makes specializing very potent. To err with skill point allocation is human, but the game is very forgiving with skill point refunds except for masteries. It starts out fairly cheap and slowly increases in price the more you use it, but I’ve used it for over 120+ skill points without destroying my wallet.Grim Dawn also has a Devotion system which reminds me of Path of Exile’s giant passive tree, but smaller. The Devotion system is made of many constellations which mostly provide passive bonuses and some on-chance abilities which can result in meteor showers, whirlpools, a shield, and more. You must find and cleanse shrines out in the world to earn Devotion points and most of them are out of the way or hidden. Every completed constellation provides affinity for unlocking more powerful constellations which makes things complicated. Planning will be required here since refunding skill points is more difficult. You’ll need Aether Crystals (a material) and iron bits (the currency) for each point.For my main character, I went with a Druid (Shaman + Arcanist) that heavily used the refund system to create a fun character that could handle the challenges of the game set to Veteran. My character underwent some drastic changes as she went from a melee focused lightning Shaman with a pet and some Arcanist abilities to a cold/lightning Arcanist that later added two aether/fire skills found deep within the tree. I mainly used Olexra’s Flash Freeze, a damaging AoE freeze attack; a Lightning Nova from an Amber gem; and Trozan’s Sky Shard, basically 3 ice meteors. I greatly enjoyed freezing all the enemies on the screen and then following up with the other two spells. Eventually, I picked up Aether Ray for that single target beam of death feeling and Devastation to complete my AoE build. The spells and skills are satisfying and impactful once you have your arsenal together. Some of them send the enemies flying. You should definitely use the refund system to maximize your character’s potential.The game has crafting and it’s the kind of crafting where you make one item that’s then needed for another, more powerful item. Example, 3-4 pieces make 1 complete ingredient. Item A, B, and C each require four different complete ingredients. Item Q requires A, B, and C. This kind of progression is tied to crafting materials and Relics. It also lets you try and roll rare gear if you have the Scrap, but I wouldn’t recommend it unless you’re trying to replace very low level gear. You can farm materials off of specific monsters, including bosses. To repopulate a world, you’ll need to exit to the main menu and then start the game again which goes by quickly for my system, but still isn’t fun to do. The crafting system requires enough farming to the point of multiple restarts or playthroughs in order to make the more interesting items. In my case, I couldn’t make a Relic I strongly desired because I didn’t find the right blueprint drop for one of the ingredients over my 70+ hours on that single character which made me sigh repeatedly. Still does. I had all the other pieces that went through the process.Finally, there’s a reputation system in play. Enemy factions will grow stronger as you kill more of them which results in better drops. Allied factions will offer more items from their faction merchants. They carry good equipment and make sure you stay appropriately geared if the drops were not in your favor. You can do bounties for a faction to increase your reputation with them, complete relevant quest, or kill the monster types they dislike. Bounties are vaguely described kill quests and not very interesting.Coop Experience Grim Dawn has functional p2p online co-op which works out pretty well for the most part. You’ll never have to worry about servers shutting down or server maintenance, but at the same time, you better make sure all players involved have some decent connections since one of you will be the host. The only disruptive things I’ve noticed were some rare desync issues where you can lose track of the other player’s true position (summons will follow the real deal) and some dead monsters/enemies that stayed behind in odd positions, their bodies normally decay to nothingness. Some player abilities will synergize well together. In my case, I used my max level Olexra’s Flash Freeze to reduce the enemies’ fire resistance by 106% which greatly benefited my co-op partner who dealt 80-90% fire damage. -Grim Dawn is a fairly good ARPG that should keep you entertained for many hours. For me, it has a low replay value. It’s a game that I might check on every now and then. I do have an interest in seeing what future mods might be able to accomplish once the tools are ready since the other ARPGs I play are online only. You can also use a trainer with GD with no issues online or offline. Should you decide to give this game a chance, I’ll point out two useful resources for beginning players: http://www.grimdawn.com/game.php which is a game guide and http://grimcalc.com/ for skill tree planning.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2016
												Did Diablo 3 took your lunch money and stomped on your childhood memories? Look no further. This ARPG is the best I had played since old school Diablo 2. No Hello Kitty Island Adventures graphics (Diablo 3/Torchlight) but with a darker and serious yet unique gore art direction. I can't deal with cartoonish graphic that Blizzard seems to go for.Moreover you can customise your character build as much as you want and not limited to Blizzards skill system that a 1year can design. The dual class as well as old school of skill and stat points are found in Grim Dawn. They further expand the customisation with Devotion points which you have to unlock and you can level the devotion skills and assign them to your minions or skill too!Did I just mention minions? The minions in Grim Dawn are actually useful unlike Diablo 3's minion which seems to serve aesthetic purposes only since they just tear like paper.Crafting system is quite simple yet purposeful (you can use your materials for crafting or imbued it into your gear) and I love that they gave you a lot of inventory space to hoard your loots. Character progression never seem to miss the mark. Even if you finish 'Normal' difficulty, there are other devotion skill points to be unlock on other difficulty modes. The amount of tender loving effects put into the game is amazing, I might have epilepsy with all the things going on sometime during a big fight.Most ARPG seems to have the bread but missing the nutella topping, Grim Dawn delivers both. Definitely a well made game and you should give it a try.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have been a fan of ARPG's since their conception with the original Diablo game, and as time has moved on there have been more and more games come out. Having played Titan Quest I loved the engine and how it all work. So when the latest round of ARPG's were announced I was excited, a new Diablo, Path of Exile etc It seemed great but having played the most that were on offer, I found that nothing queld my thirst for blood and loot like Grim Dawn. I come back to this game time and time again, every new build I play through at least twice, trying different classes and builds and find more stuff, and everytime I am wanting more, to the point like I said I play through it yet again. Never have I experienced an ARPG as addictive as this one. What makes it addictive? I believe it is a combination of good game play, customisation of a character taht makes it truely yours and just great game mechanics; Items are upgraded easily, unique items can be upgraded, and the effects (visually) of some items just look great e.g. my flaming boots and green smoking helmet. Visually this game is great, hands down more Grim Dark than most other ARPGs. I kickstarted this game and it has been one of the best investments I have made, a solid game that leaves you wanting more. If you are willing to loose hours to a game, then let me recommend this one.

content:
Posted: February 29, 2016
												Grim Dawn is made by the same people who did the Titan Quest series, so if you liked those you'll enjoy this for sure.  As someone who has thousands of hours under my belt playing ARPGs going all the way back to the original Diablo, I feel like this game strikes a nice balance in terms of complexity between Diablo 3 (modest) and Path of Exile (very high).  Between the 6 classes, the possibility to Dual Class, unique gear, and Devotion system there is a lot of depth and build diversity here to keep you busy for 100+ hours.  If there are any useless skills in this game, I haven't found them yet.  Everything is viable.  My current favorite is a Druid build where I run around with a rifle that shoots lightning everywhere, I call it the Boomstick build in tribute to Ash from Evil Dead.
